program: Rural Energy for America Program Renewable Energy Systems and Energy Efficiency Improvement Loans and Grants
funding_code: MAND. RENEW ENERFY SYSTEMS GRANTS UNDER $20,000
naics_industry_sector: Agriculture, Forestry, Fishing and Hunting (11)
naics_description: OTHER VEGETABLE (EXCEPT POTATO) AND MELON FARMING
project_announced_description: This Rural Development investment will be used to help Matthew Draper purchase and install a 3.75 kilowatts (kW) solar power array. Mr. Draper owns and operates a small agriculture production farm growing vegetables and chicken egg production in the Village of Los Ranchos de Albuquerque, New Mexico. After installation, the solar system will save the business $1,129.00 in its annual electric bill. The new solar system will generate 6,955 in kilowatt hours (kW) of electricity which is equal to 97 percent of the electricity this agriculture operation uses every year.

borrower_name: NEW MEXICO WINE & GRAPE GROWERS ASSOC.
funding_code: LAMP VALUE ADDED PRODUCER GRANT MANDATORY
naics_industry_sector: Manufacturing (31-33)
project_announced_description: This Rural Development investment will be used to create the VIVAVINO wine bar. The VIVAVINO wine bar will be established and function as a "wine welcome center" offering tourism information and a tasting room that will sample and sell locally made wine. The grant will provide much needed working capital to start the project, and the project will bring more attention to the growing New Mexico wine industry. The VIVAVINO will be a catalyst for growth in New Mexico wine.

program: Rural Energy for America Program Renewable Energy Systems and Energy Efficiency Improvement Loans and Grants
funding_code: MAND. RENEW ENERFY SYSTEMS GRANTS UNDER $20,000
naics_industry_sector: Accommodation and Food Services (72)
project_announced_description: This Rural Development investment is be used to help Burnt Well Guest Ranch LLC purchase and install a 15.68 kilowatts (kW) solar power array. After installation, the solar system will save the business $3,166 in its annual electric bill. The new solar system will generate 28,788 in kilowatt hours (kW) of electricity which is equal to 98.03 percent of the electricity this operation uses every year. Located in Roswell, New Mexico, the Burnt Well Guest Ranch is a working cattle ranch. Guests staying at the ranch will be immersed in the day-to-day ranching operations, and the "Cowboy/Cowgirl" lifestyle. Theyll learn how to rope, ride a horse, and take part in cattle drives and how to manage cattle. After a day of working on the range, guests will relax and have the opportunity to enjoy, campfires, playing horseshoes, hiking, bird watching, star gazing and more. And of course, the guests are fed home cooked cowboy family style meals.

program: Rural Energy for America Program Renewable Energy Systems and Energy Efficiency Improvement Loans and Grants
funding_code: REAP-MANDATORY RENEW ENERGY SYST GRANTS
naics_industry_sector: Real Estate and Rental and Leasing (53)
naics_description: LESSORS OF RESIDENTIAL BUILDINGS AND DWELLINGS
project_announced_description: This Rural Development investment will be used to purchase and install a 60.8 kW Solar PV System by Seddin Investments LLC that operates a resort called, "The Retreat at Angel Fire" in Angel Fire, N.M. Located in the high mountains in the northern part of the state the family owned resort consists of ten fully furnished cabins on twelve private acres. After installation, the solar system will save the business $12,911.00 in its annual electric bill. The solar system will generate 94,773 in kilowatt-hours of electricity which is equal to 290% of the electricity this business uses every year. Making this financial outlay a very good investment for Seddin Investments LLC.

program: Rural Energy for America Program Renewable Energy Systems and Energy Efficiency Improvement Loans and Grants
funding_code: REAP-MAND ENERGY EFF IMPROV GRANTS
naics_industry_sector: Real Estate and Rental and Leasing (53)
naics_description: LESSORS OF RESIDENTIAL BUILDINGS AND DWELLINGS
project_announced_description: This Rural Development investment will be used to help Seddin Investments LLC purchase and install energy efficient heating, ventilation, and air conditioning units, water heaters, insulation and cook stoves. This investment will save the business $22,382.00 in its annual electric bill. The improvements will generate 98,550 in kilowatts (kW) of electricity and 3,920 in LP Gas savings equal to 54 percent of the electricity this hospitality business uses every year. Seddin Investments LLC is a family owned business which operates a ten-cabin resort business located in the Village of Angel Fire, New Mexico.

program: Rural Energy for America Program Renewable Energy Systems and Energy Efficiency Improvement Loans and Grants
funding_code: MAND.ENERGY EFFIC IMPROV GRANTS UNDER $20,000
naics_industry_sector: Manufacturing (31-33)
project_announced_description: This Rural Development investment will be used to purchase and install energy efficient equipment for a meat processing facility in Raton, New Mexico. High Country Meats serves the greater Raton area in northeast New Mexico and southern Colorado. When the upgrades are completed the new equipment will save $2,196.00 per year in electric bills for High Country Meats. This amounts to 13,392 kilowatt hours of electricity or 36 percent of the businesses electric usage each year. The savings is enough electricity to power a single average sized home.

borrower_name: REGENTS OF NEW MEXICO STATE UNIVERSITY
funding_code: RBCS ENTERPRISE GRANTS
naics_industry_sector: Educational Services (61)
project_announced_description: This Rural Development Investment of $99,998 will be used to conduct performance assessments and energy audits for eight grocery stores in small rural communities in New Mexico for the purpose of identifying operational improvements that can be made to increase store income and the chance for survivability. The increasing demise of grocery stores in small rural communities results in food deserts, related health issues and job loss. This investment is intended to help slow this troubling trend across New Mexico.

funding_code: LAMP VALUE ADDED PRODUCER GRANT MANDATORY
naics_industry_sector: Agriculture, Forestry, Fishing and Hunting (11)
project_announced_description: This Rural Development investment will be used by 4-A Packing LLC to convert fresh chile peppers into a ready-to-eat Chile Relleno Pack. The company will flame roast, peel, and stuff the chile with cheese, and then batter and fry the fresh chile creating a chile relleno. 4-A Packing, LLC is proficient when turning chile peppers into other products. Theyve made a chile oil, kabobs, and many other items with their fresh green chile. Their chile is grown in the Hatch Valley in the southern part of New Mexico. Also, their chile is branded under the Hatch Green Chilecertification which guarantees this chile pepper is certified and is grown in Hatch, New Mexico.The obligation of funds for this project will help create at least 18 new jobs in the Dona Ana County area.

funding_code: LAMP VALUE ADDED PRODUCER GRANT MANDATORY
naics_industry_sector: Agriculture, Forestry, Fishing and Hunting (11)
project_announced_description: This Rural Development investment will be used by Jinglebob Land and Cattle Company, LLC, along with supplemental funding, to develop and implement a marketing plan for its beef products. Jinglebob will add e-commerce to its website, for direct orders, and will conduct an advertising campaign to increase awareness and sales of its grass-fed beef products. As a result of this market expansion project, Jinglebob Land & Cattle LLC, located in Anthony, N.M., expects to double its customer base and increase its sales and income. The increase in sales is projected to support the creation of three additional fulltime jobs.

funding_code: COMBINATION CF DIRECT LOAN/GRANT
naics_industry_sector: Public Administration (92)
project_announced_description: This Rural Development investment will be used by the Village of Hatch, New Mexico to purchase four fully equipped patrol vehicles with police equipment packages. This will include all associated equipment to make the vehicles fully operational for the Hatch Police Department. The new police cars are needed to replace the four oldest vehicles in the patrol fleet, which are near or past their useful effective life. The old patrol vehicles have become unreliable due to high usage, mileage, and require constant maintenance. The low reliability of these older vehicles places the police officers driving them and public safety at great risk. The new police vehicles play an important role in the community by enabling the police officers to quickly respond to emergency calls and to provide a safe environment where the 1,650 citizens of Hatch, New Mexico live, work, and socialize in this agricultural community.

borrower_name: Lower Rio Grande Public Water Works Authority
project_name: South Valley Water Supply & Treatment Project
funding_code: PERSISTENT POVERTY (LOAN ONLY) WATER ONLY
naics_industry_sector: Utilities (22)
project_announced_description: This Rural Development investment will be used to provide additional financing to upgrade and modernize the Berino, New Mexico water system. The financing package made to the Lower Rio Grande Public Water Works Authority will be used to drill a new water well within 100 feet of the old existing well. When completed the updated water system will also address the arsenic concentrations in the groundwater in the Berino area and provide cleaner water to the residents of Berino. To do so the installation of an arsenic treatment facility and a new storage tank is included in this construction project. The expanded water service will create a redundant water supply source for the residents of Berino. This is being done in case the nearby Mesquite and Desert Sands water systems are not able to provide enough water as a back-up service to the Berino water system in an emergency. The improvements will benefit the 874 residential users and 16 commercial users currently serviced by the Berino water system.

funding_code: (SECD) CF GRANTS
naics_industry_sector: Other or Not Defined
project_announced_description: This Rural Development investment will be used to bring a donated portable building into compliance with the American with Disabilities Act (ADA) for El Grito Inc. head start program located in Silver City in southwestern New Mexico. By making the portable building ADA compliant it will meet the New Mexico Early Childhood Education and Care Department licensing requirements. The use of the additional classrooms will allow for social distancing requirements set forth in New Mexico because of the COVID-19 pandemic. The renovation to the building must be completed before the structure can be occupied. The additional 2 classrooms can accommodate a total of 32 children and 4 teachers. El Grito is a head start program that mostly serves three and four old children with special needs from low-income families.

naics_industry_sector: Other or Not Defined
project_announced_description: This Rural Development investment will be used to bring a donated portable building into compliance with the American with Disabilities Act (ADA) for El Grito Inc. head start program located in Silver City in southwestern New Mexico. By making the portable building ADA compliant it will meet the New Mexico Early Childhood Education and Care Department licensing requirements. The use of the additional classrooms will allow for social distancing requirements set forth in New Mexico because of the COVID-19 pandemic. The renovation to the building must be completed before the structure can be occupied. The additional 2 classrooms can accommodate a total of 32 children and 4 teachers. El Grito is a head start program that mostly serves three and four old children with special needs from low-income families.

funding_code: (GRANT ONLY) 306C  WATER ONLY (COLONIAS)
naics_industry_sector: Utilities (22)
project_announced_description: This Rural Development investment will be used to upgrade the water system in the city of Lordsburg, New Mexico. The upgrade is necessary to comply with the most recent administrative compliance order issued by the New Mexico Environmental Department Drinking Water Bureau which mandates better service and quality of water to the citizens of Lordsburg. To comply with the order the water distribution system will see the replacement of 27,000 linear feet of existing small diameter line with larger waterlines as well as connections and fire hydrants for improved fire safety. Also, the funding will address inadequate water pressure in three different areas of the city, the project includes the rehabilitation of two pressure relief stations. To provide proper water treatment and fluoride removal, a new building will be constructed to house a three-stage, one pass, reverse osmosis system. The new treatment facility will connect to the existing infrastructure including the wells, storage tank and a booster station. The current municipal water system in the city of Lordsburg was developed like most older municipalities, out of necessity to address the growing demands of its residents. Because of this, the system components vary in age, anywhere from a couple of months to 80 years. The water system needs a variety of improvements to increase the citys water service, efficiency and reduce overall operations and maintenance costs. Due to the large number of improvements this funding will complete the second phase of construction. The first phase which was also funded by Rural Development in 2019 provided necessary improvement to water source, transmission, and distribution issues. The city of Lordsburg is a designated colonia in the State of New Mexico and has been able to take advantage of the Rural Development colonia-specific grant funding. In addition to being a designated colonia, the city resides in Hidalgo County which is considered a "Persistent Poverty County" which has allowed the city of Lordsburg to take advantage of these specific loan funds at our lowest interest rate.

funding_code: SECD RB DEV ENTERPRISE GRANT
naics_industry_sector: Public Administration (92)
project_announced_description: This Rural Development investment will be used to expand the production of the Fresh Chile Companys red chile sauces. Based in Las Cruces, New Mexico. the Fresh Chile Company will use the financing to increase its production of canning raw fresh red chile because of higher demand for the product. The process to can the red chile includes boiling, straining, seasoning, acidifying and jarring the shelf stable product. The result of this investment will allow Fresh Chile Company to grow its business and market the canned red chile throughout New Mexico and the region.

program: Rural Energy for America Program Renewable Energy Systems and Energy Efficiency Improvement Loans and Grants
funding_code: REAP-MANDATORY RENEW ENERGY SYST GRANTS
naics_industry_sector: Manufacturing (31-33)
project_announced_description: This Rural Development investment will be used to help New Mexico Wineries Incorporated purchase and install a 271.92 kilowatts (kW) solar power array. The Lescombes family has been making wine for six generations and moved their operation to southern New Mexico where they planted their first vines in 1981. The solar power system will be used to power various types of equipment used to make the wine they produce. This investment will save the business $39,769 in its annual electric bill. The new solar system will generate 497,122 in kilowatt hours (kWh) of electricity which is equal to 51 percent of the electricity this agriculture operation uses every year.

project_announced_description: This Rural Development investment will be used to purchase much need vehicles for Navajo Technical University (NTU) an educational institution located inCrownpoint, New Mexico located within the Dine Community (Navajo Nation).The financial support is being used to purchase three 15 passenger vans with towing package and one four door sedan vehicle. NTU has been providing science andtechnology curriculum since 1985. They are dedicated to providing a state-of-arttechnology to the Navajo Nation based upon the Dine culture and traditions. Thecampus is available to all Native American students.

funding_code: RBCS ENTERPRISE GRANTS
naics_industry_sector: Public Administration (92)
project_announced_description: This Rural Development investment will be used by Mora Creative Council, along with $6,800 in supplemental funding, to purchase freezers and refrigeration equipment for Los de Mora Local Growers Cooperative. Los de Mora has been operating a part-time retail market since the local grocery store closed as well as distributing locally produced food to other regional communities. The equipment will increase its capacity to serve the local and regional markets. The Coop has 36 members whose income will increase with the additional sales. Mora Creative Council is a designated New Mexico MainStreet organization. Part of the funding will be used to purchase signs for Los de Mora and the Mora Plaza as well a digital kiosk to provide information to visitors and tourists. Mora County is a persistent poverty community with a population of approximately 4,800 and a median household income of $26,968. This investment is intended to increase the sales and income for the local coop member/producers.

funding_code: RBCS ENTERPRISE GRANTS
naics_industry_sector: Public Administration (92)
project_announced_description: This Rural Development investment will be used by to assist with the expansion of four existing small businesses. Collins Lake Ranch provides residential and educational services for adults with developmental disabilities and employment for Mora community members. The equipment provided through this investment is expected to result in the creation of three new jobs. Theresas Tamales will receive tables and chairs for outdoor dining to adapt to COVID safety requirements. The investment will help retain one full time employee and create one part time job. Collaborative Visions will receive additional equipment for its certified commercial kitchen where entrepreneurs process food products from locally grown crops. Mora Valley Community Health Services will receive a small loader that will create one part time construction job for maintaining its properties. The job creation made possible with this investment will have a positive impact.

funding_code: SECTION 306 FFB - OTHER ELECTRIC FFB - OTHER LOAN PERSISTENT POVERTY
naics_industry_sector: Utilities (22)
project_announced_description: This Rural Development investment will be used to connect 124 consumers, build and improve 118 miles of line, transmission and headquarters facilities projects. This loan includes $1,459,000 in smart grid technologies. Springer Electric is headquartered in Springer, New Mexico, and provides service to 3,667 customers over 1,837 miles of line in the counties of Colfax, Harding, Mora, San Miguel and Union in northeastern New Mexico.

funding_code: DLT GRANTS- CARES ACT - MEDICAL
naics_industry_sector: Utilities (22)
project_announced_description: This Rural Development investment will be used to provide remote medical, dental and behavioral health care services for underserved and uninsured patients, and distance learning education for health care professionals in Dona Ana, Luna, Otero and Sierra counties. An interactive system involving telemedicine carts with accessories will enable live audio-video interactions between health care professionals and patients. Teleconference equipment for conference rooms will facilitate distance learning and group sessions, and laptops for medical, dental and behavioral providers will be used to provide services to patients in rural communities.

funding_code: DISTANCE LEARNING- GRANT
naics_industry_sector: Utilities (22)
project_announced_description: This Rural Development investment will be used to assist the Health Education and Access to Learning (HEAL) Project. The HEAL Project will deliver distance learning to rural and exceptionally rural individuals in Northern Dona Ana, Sierra, Otero and Luna Counties, New Mexico. The HEAL Project will affect an estimate 97,000 people directly or indirectly in southern New Mexico.

funding_code: DISTANCE LEARNING- GRANT
naics_industry_sector: Utilities (22)
project_announced_description: This Rural Development investment will be used to create a distance learning hub/end-user site at the main campus in Las Vegas, and at a second end-user site in Mora, N.M. The system will eliminate barriers to higher education for residents of remote communities in San Miguel and Mora counties. This funding will enable New Mexico Highlands University to offer remote courses and to implement remote student support programs (especially for STEM students). In addition to equipping the remote site, the project will fund the purchase of computers configured specifically for distance learning. These computers will be loaned to students. The Mora site also be made available to community members for activities such as workforce development.

funding_code: DLT OPIOID GRANTS
naics_industry_sector: Utilities (22)
project_announced_description: This Rural Development investment will be used to purchase telemedicine equipment to help Santa Teresa Childrens Day and Night Clinic implement a comprehensive health care and wellness programs. Six fully-equipped and upgraded telemedicine carts will be provided to five hub/end-user sites. These sites include three elementary schools and two community clinics. Each site will have the capacity to receive primary care services for children and adults, womens health, and mental health and behavior services, including substance misuse prevention and treatment. The sites are expected to serve approximately 14,000 people in Dona Ana, Socorro, Sierra and Union counties.

project_announced_description: This Rural Development investment will be used to help McGinn Enterprises Incorporated purchase and install a 11.85 kilowatts (kW) solar array. project_name: FY2021 B&I WC REFI CELL TOWERS
funding_code: GUARANTEED B&I 3% FEE LOAN
naics_industry_sector: Construction (23)
naics_description: POWER AND COMMUNICATION LINE AND RELATED STRUCTURES CONSTRUCTION
project_announced_description: This Rural Development investment will be used to refinance a line of credit and provide permanent working capital to Hemphill Towers I LLC who operates17 cell towers. The towers are in various rural locations in New Mexico, Montana, North Dakota, andTexas.Seven of the 17 cell towers are in New Mexico in the towns ofFruitland, Malaga, Milan, Roswell,Tierra Amarilla, Thoreau, and Tres Piedras. Hemphill Towers I, LLC leases space to cell phone carriers such as Verizon and AT&T, enabling the delivery of vital telecommunication services to rural areas. The loan will create five jobs.

funding_code: CF GRANTS
naics_industry_sector: Other or Not Defined
project_announced_description: This Rural Development investment will be used by Las Cumbres Community Services (LCCS) to purchase two vehicles with handicapped equipment packages that meet the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA) requirements. These vehicles are specially fitted with rear mounted National Highway Traffic Safety Administration (NHTSA) compliant rear lifts with ADA compliant interlock systems. The vans will also be equipped with tie down systems, back-up cameras and internal surveillance systems. The need for the new vans is to replace two vans in LCCS fleet. The old vans are being replaced because of their age and their upkeep has become cost prohibitive. One of the new vans will be used for Adult Services and the other for the New Mexico Pre-K therapeutic preschool program. LCCS provides these services to adults with developmental and intellectual disabilities (ID/DD) and to children, ages 0 8, and their families. Services include community inclusion programs; employment; community support for groups and individuals; independent living and living care supports; and therapeutic preschool for children. LCCS began offering its services in 1970 to the residents of north central New Mexico. LCCS provides its services to low-income residents who live in rural communities that experience challenges accessing specialized health resources.Today, because of its expansion of services to southern New Mexico, LCCS has become one of the largest social service providers in the state. Each year LCCS helps over 7,000 people with its programs.

funding_code: (GRANT ONLY) 306C-NATIVE AMERICAN-WASTE ONLY
naics_industry_sector: Utilities (22)
project_announced_description: This Rural Development investment will be used to build and extend sewer services at San Ildefonso Pueblo located in north central New Mexico. These services will provide additional connections for 34 homes and will add five additional connections for Tribal facilities in the Pueblo Center and the Pueblo South area. The residents that will be served with the upgraded sewer system are currently on a severely outdated septic system. The funds will be used to demolish and lay new sewer lines, including cleanouts access to eliminate the health and sanitary concerns. There will be two grinder pumps built at each individual home to allow for service connection. The existing septic tanks will be emptied and demolished and two lift stations will be erected to allow for the additional flow of waste to head to the existing lagoons. Once the project is complete it will encompass a total of 132 users of the 416 residents of the Pueblo. Most households in the Pueblo are very traditional and serve as homes for many generations under one roof which makes this project critical because the residents of the Pueblo need an updated modern sewer delivery system. When completed this wastewater project will provide essential services to a community of 524 that all though small in population has the same needs when it comes to dispose of its wastewater as any other community.

funding_code: COMBINATION CF DIRECT LOAN/GRANT
naics_industry_sector: Public Administration (92)
project_announced_description: This Rural Development investment will be used to purchase three law enforcement vehicles that will be equipped with the gear. The gear includes all associated equipment to make the vehicles fully operational for the police department. The village of Cuba law enforcement department needs the new cars to replace the three old vehicles in the patrol fleet. All three vehicles are near or past their useful effective life because they have become unreliable due to high usage, high mileage, and require constant maintenance. These old vehicles are not reliable and place the safety of the officers and public at great risk because they can hinder the police officers to answer to emergency calls. The new police vehicles will play an important role in the community by enabling the department to quickly respond to emergency calls and to provide better service and safety to this community of 593 residents located in northwest New Mexico.

naics_industry_sector: Other or Not Defined
project_announced_description: This Rural Development investment to the Institute of American Indian Art (IAIA) an educational institution located near Santa Fe, New Mexico will be used to purchase solar panels for their Center for Lifelong Education building. IAIA is a member of the Climate Action Task Force to reduce their carbon footprint. The purchase and installation of the solar panels will assist the entity in decreasing their electricity consumption and in meeting their goal to improve the environment. The IAIA is one of the colleges covered by the Equity in Education Land-Grant Status Act of 1994. The school is dedicated to providing a national center of research, training, and scholarship for Native Americans who are interested in Native art and culture. The majority of thepopulation attending the college is Native American; however, the campus is opento all worldwide.

funding_code: (WWA PROGRAM AREA) SOLID WASTE GRANT
naics_industry_sector: Utilities (22)
project_announced_description: The Rural Development grant investment will be used to continue its work in providing education, demonstration, and technical assistance, and to implement better land management practices. The funds will be used to create new partnerships toward the development of measurable composting programs with farmers and ranchers in Ranchos de Taos, New Mexico. By partnering with contractors and other local stakeholders, this program will provide both technical assistance and training to protect water quality and quantity during agricultural operations. The work will also achieve the benefits of waste diversion, reduced carbon emissions, and improved soil health. Ranchos de Taos has a population of just over 2,500 residents.

funding_code: (COMB LOAN & GRANT) WATER ONLY
naics_industry_sector: Utilities (22)
project_announced_description: This Rural Development investment will be used to finance phase two of the replacement of the existing water transmission lines and install pressure relief valves throughout water system providing service to the city of Truth or Consequences, (T or C) New Mexico. In addition, all water meters will be replaced with new automatic radio read meters.The upgraded water transmission lines are badly needed because the current water system is plagued with a significant amount of water loss due to pipe breakage. The current water lines are considered aged by today standards as no significant work has been done to upgrade the system since the 1930s. The updated water system will replace the aging infrastructure, inadequate pipe sizes and will provide consistent water pressure and will do away with wasted water.The new water system will also allow improved fire protection because of the better water flow and will also allow future reasonable population growth. Located in south central New Mexico, about 75 miles northwest of Las Cruces, T or C has a population of 5,753 and is the center of governmental and commercial activity in Sierra County. The neighboring village of Williamsburg will also benefit from the upgrades because the village receives its water service from the T or C water system.

funding_code: ECONOMIC IMPACT INITIATIVE GRANTS
naics_industry_sector: Other or Not Defined
naics_description: OTHER PUBLIC BUILDING & IMPROVEMENT RELATED SERVICES
project_announced_description: This Rural Development investment will be used by the city of Socorro, New Mexico to purchase a new street sweeper for its road department. The street sweeper will be used throughout the 14.4 square miles that make up the city. The street sweeper is needed in order to help maintain and control debris and dirt throughout the community. The street sweeping not only makes the streets cleaner, but it is an important part of storm water pollution prevention. It prevents unwanted materials from flowing into the storm drains which could cause backups and flooding. The new street sweeper will also help the city of Socorro look better because dirty streets leave a bad impression on visitors, especially if theyre visiting Socorro for the first time. By keeping the streets of Socorro clean it confirms to visitors the community has pride in itself showing the city is a nice place to live and work.

funding_code: ECONOMIC IMPACT INITIATIVE GRANTS
naics_industry_sector: Other or Not Defined
naics_description: OTHER PUBLIC BUILDING & IMPROVEMENT RELATED SERVICES
project_announced_description: This Rural Development investment will be used to purchase two backhoe tractors by the city of Socorro, New Mexico. The backhoes are needed for utility work to maintain gas supply lines and the water and wastewater distribution lines throughout the 14.4 square miles that make up the city of 9,000 people. Specifically, the equipment will be used on an everyday basis to maintain the infrastructure to make sure basic services are provided to the citizens throughout the city. This is especially important to ensure natural gas is delivered without interruption. Also, the equipment will be used to fix water and wastewater line breaks. By doing so the city of Socorro will be protecting drinking water by making sure it is safe and healthy. The city of Socorro qualified for a Persistent Poverty Grant and an Economic Impact Initiative grant from USDA Rural Development because of the citys poverty rate which is estimated at 30.9% .

funding_code: PERSISTENT POVERTY (LOAN ONLY) WASTE DISPOSAL ONLY
naics_industry_sector: Utilities (22)
project_announced_description: This Rural Development investment will be used to provide additional financing to the city of Socorro. They have upgraded and replaced the interceptor sewer lines which were no longer structurally sound. Several lift stations have also been replaced, and additional funding is needed for additives for several roadways that will increase the functionality and operation. The additional funding will pay for a backup generator and concrete pad with the ultimate goal of replacing older sewer lines. This project is a high priority as most of the city of Socorro is served through a centralized gravity sewer collection system. The community has also been identified as a persistent poverty area, with this project serving approximately 9,051 residents in Socorro, N.M.

funding_code: PERSISTENT POVERTY (LOAN ONLY) WASTE DISPOSAL ONLY
naics_industry_sector: Utilities (22)

funding_code: GUARANTEED B&I 3% FEE LOAN
naics_industry_sector: Accommodation and Food Services (72)
project_announced_description: This Rural Development investment will be used to refinance debts, working capital, and financing of fees to the owners of the historic Sagebrush Inn in Taos, N.M. When the Inn opened 90 years ago in 1931 it offered 13 guestrooms and quickly became known for its authentic Southwest dcor. Today, the hotel is still known for its southwestern architectural style and now consists of 156 units that offers Wi-Fi, a swimming pool, a spa tub, a restaurant, and laundry services. Over the years numerous celebrities have stayed at the Sagebrush Inn; and movies such as Easy Rider and Twins were shot in and around the hotel. This project will save 100 jobs and will create 50 new jobs.

program: Rural Energy for America Program Renewable Energy Systems and Energy Efficiency Improvement Loans and Grants
funding_code: MAND. RENEW ENERFY SYSTEMS GRANTS UNDER $20,000
naics_industry_sector: Information (51)
project_announced_description: This Rural Development investment will be used to help KTAO-FM radio purchase and install a 16 kilowatts (kW) energy storage battery backup system. The radio station is known to be the first and largest solar powered radio station in the United States. The KTAO-FM began using solar power to run its transmitter located on top of 10,801 Picuris Peak south of Taos; this was necessary because there is not an electric power line located in the area. The battery backup system being purchased by this grant opportunity which will ensure the radio station can operate if its power source is interrupted.

program: Rural Energy for America Program Renewable Energy Systems and Energy Efficiency Improvement Loans and Grants
funding_code: MAND. RENEW ENERFY SYSTEMS GRANTS UNDER $20,000
naics_industry_sector: Information (51)
naics_description: DATA PROCESSING, HOSTING, AND RELATED SERVICES
project_announced_description: This Rural Development investment will be used to help Brownrice Internet Incorporated purchase and install a 30 kilowatts (kW) solar photovoltaic array/parking canopy. When the solar system is installed the business will see $7,595 annual energy savings. The new solar system will generate 50,635 in kilowatt hours (kWh) of electricity which is equal to 40.47 percent of the electricity the business uses every year. The new solar system array will generate enough electricity to power five average sized homes.

funding_code: CF GRANTS
naics_industry_sector: Public Administration (92)
project_announced_description: This Rural Development investment will be used to purchase two police vehicles for the town of Mountainair. The need for the vehicles is due to their current police vehicles fleet being aged with high mileage and constant need of repairs. The low dependability of the older vehicles puts the public safety at greater risk. Their police department needs dependable vehicles, which are essential to keep the community safe and them being able to do their job. The new vehicles will play an important role in the community to provide quick responses, to solve criminal actives, as well as provide a safe community.

funding_code: LOCAL AGRICULTURE MARKET RESOURCE PROGRAM (LAMP) VALUE-ADDED PRODUCER GRANTS - COVID
naics_industry_sector: Wholesale Trade (42)
naics_description: DRUGS AND DRUGGISTS' SUNDRIES MERCHANT WHOLESALERS
project_announced_description: This Rural Development investment will be used to help Bluefly Farms LLC for the manufacturing, marketing, and labeling of their lavender herbal sparkling water line. Bluefly Farms was founded in 2013 and has been growing lavender since then in the Rio Grande Valley in Peralta, New Mexico with an area population of 3,615 residents. Since its founding, Bluefly Farms has made various products from the lavender from soaps to the herbal sparkling water. The products are marketed in a variety of ways from farmers markets to being sold at various shops, breweries, cafs, and spas in Albuquerque, Cedar Crest, Corrales and Santa Fe, New Mexico. The funding provided by this grant will be used specifically by Bluefly Farms to expand its herbal sparkling water line business. With the expansion of its production of the herbal sparkling water line Bluefly Farms will create a full-time job and create two additional part-time staff positions.

funding_code: (COMB LOAN & GRANT) WATER ONLY
naics_industry_sector: Utilities (22)
project_announced_description: This Rural Development investment will be used to provide additional funding to build an Arsenic Water Treatment Facility to treat water from the city of Belen well number 8. Well number 8 currently contains water that exceeds drinking standards for arsenic set by the Environmental Protect Agency (EPA) and the State of New Mexico drinking water standards. Therefore, by building the facility to treat the water to lower the arsenic it will remove the health and sanitary issue and bring the city of Belen water back to required drinking water standards.

funding_code: (COMB LOAN & GRANT) WATER ONLY
naics_industry_sector: Utilities (22)
project_announced_description: This Rural Development investment will be used to provide additional funding to build an Arsenic Water Treatment Facility to treat water from the city of Belen well number 8. Well number 8 currently contains water that exceeds drinking standards for arsenic set by the Environmental Protect Agency (EPA) and the State of New Mexico drinking water standards. Therefore, by building the facility to treat the water to lower the arsenic it will remove the health and sanitary issue and bring the city of Belen water back to required drinking water standards.

funding_code: PERSISTENT POVERTY (GRANT ONLY) 306C-NATIVE AMERICAN-WASTE ONLY
naics_industry_sector: Utilities (22)
project_announced_description: This Rural Development investment will be used to modify the existing Pueblo of Laguna, Mesita Village east lagoon wastewater system with an additional lagoon cell. The Pueblo of Laguna is in Cibola County in western New Mexico and serves a total of 4,043 tribal residents. The Pueblo of Laguna and the Pueblos Water Utility Authority with assistance from Indian Health Services (IHS), has successfully installed multiple projects over the years with USDA Rural Development financing to repair and rehabilitate the entire wastewater and sewer system for the pueblo. The Mesita Village Lagoon Expansion will be one of those successes when the old and failing septic systems and leach fields are replaced. The current wastewater system is causing a strain on the Utility Authoritys maintenance team and budget, as well as presenting potential health risks to those residents living in Mesita Village. The new lagoon cell will increase evaporation to balance the projected wastewater inflows from the abandoned septic systems and will provide adequate capacity for potential community growth through year 2040. In addition, the project will provide for another 20 years of wastewater treatment and handling for the Mesita Village East community. This project will also bring the system into compliance with health and safety, building and environmental codes.

funding_code: DISCRETION ASSIST MICROPENTERPRENUERS
naics_industry_sector: Finance and Insurance (52)
project_announced_description: This Rural Development investment will be used to provide technical assistance to microentrepreneurs located in rural areas of New Mexico, Nevada, Arizona and Texas. The delivery of technical assistance will be accomplished by Nusenda Federal Credit Union teaming up with community partners to provide financial education and training. Nusenda began serving the needs of underserved microentrepreneurs as a result of a pilot program in 2010. They were established in 1936, when eight local educators applied for a charter to form Albuquerque Public Schools Federal Credit Union. Nusenda partners with organizations that already have expertise in the needs of their communities and potential borrowers in rural tribal communities for delivery of technical assistance. Also, organizations that assist beginning farmers and ranchers, the launch of digital businesses, start-up businesses and business expansion.

program: Rural Energy for America Program Renewable Energy Systems and Energy Efficiency Improvement Loans and Grants
funding_code: REAP-MANDATORY RENEW ENERGY SYST GRANTS
naics_industry_sector: Agriculture, Forestry, Fishing and Hunting (11)
project_announced_description: This Rural Development investment will be used to assist Legend Dairy LLC purchase and install a 717.97kW solar array. Legend Dairy LLC is a third generation family-owned dairy operation established in 1992 in Clovis, New Mexico. After the solar system is installed, the business will see $89,220.00 savings in their annual electric bill. It will generate 1,274,580 kilowatt-hours of electricity which is more than 89.42 percent of the electricity the business uses every year. The photovoltaic array will generate enough electricity to power 117 homes. The purpose of REAP funding program is to assist farmers, ranchers, and rural small businesses in developing renewable energy systems, and in making energy-efficiency improvements to their operations.

program: Rural Energy for America Program Renewable Energy Systems and Energy Efficiency Improvement Loans and Grants
funding_code: REAP-MANDATORY RENEW ENERGY SYST GRANTS
naics_industry_sector: Agriculture, Forestry, Fishing and Hunting (11)
project_announced_description: This Rural Development investment will be used to help Rajen Dairy LLC purchase and install a 354.24 kW solar array. Rajen Dairy LLC, is a second and third generation family-owned dairy operation established in 1992 in Clovis, New Mexico. After the solar system is installed, the business will see $43,687.00 savings in their annual electric bill. It will generate 624,100 kilowatt-hours of electricity which is more than 74.84 percent of the electricity the business uses every year. The photovoltaic array will generate enough electricity to power 57 homes. The purpose of REAP funding program is to assist farmers, ranchers, and rural small businesses in developing renewable energy systems, and in making energy-efficiency improvements to their operations.

funding_code: CF ARP EMERGENCY RURAL HEALTH CARE GRANTS - TRACK 1 & 2
naics_industry_sector: Health Care and Social Assistance (62)
project_announced_description: This Rural Development investment will be used to purchase laptops, speakers, microphones, webcams, and training services for Mental Health Resources, Inc. (MHR) servicing staff to ensure the continuity of services during this and future pandemic events in Fort Sumner, New Mexico. Behavioral health is an integral part of health care services, and MHR is a behavioral health provider organization providing a wide range of services. During COVID-19 pandemic MHR transitioned to providing virtually all treatment, counseling, and coordination services through telehealth, including through telephonic and tele-video means, due to public health guidance and the need to continue to provide essential health care services. The transition to telehealth services was successful as the number of clients that MHR served, including new clients, during the COVID-19 pandemic have remained consistent with pre-COVID-19 clients and this transition increased the number of providers providing telehealth services in MHR service areas of Portales, Tucumcari, and Ft. Sumner.

funding_code: RBCS ENTERPRISE GRANTS
naics_industry_sector: Manufacturing (31-33)
project_announced_description: This Rural Development investmentwill be used to purchase a industrial freeze dryer by non-profit, Cruces Creative. Once purchased, Cruces Creative will lease the industrial freeze dryer to Backyard Farms, a rural small business located south of Las Cruces in the town of Vado, New Mexico (Dona Ana County). The goal of the project is to address and improve the food access, distribution and production through the creation of a new value-chain market for freeze dried fruits and vegetables. The project will provide financial growth for small farmers by providing healthier and more nutritious food options and access to underserved and vulnerable populations in food deserts and create 32 jobs in Dona Ana County.

funding_code: LAMP VALUE ADDED PRODUCER GRANT MANDATORY
naics_industry_sector: Arts, Entertainment, and Recreation (71)
project_announced_description: This Rural Development investment will be used to provide lyophilization processing technology for modification of locally grown fruits and vegetables into a freeze-dried value-added food product. The market expansion product is a ready-to-use cooking ingredient made of freeze-dried fruits and vegetables for meal preparations. The pantry packs will be ideal for large institutional cafeterias and culinary kitchens meal preparations containing long-term preservation ingredients that can be added directly to soups and stews or rehydrated to assist a healthy and nutritious diet.

funding_code: LAMP VALUE ADDED PRODUCER GRANT MANDATORY
naics_industry_sector: Agriculture, Forestry, Fishing and Hunting (11)
project_announced_description: This Rural Development investment will be used to release new Hatch Chile Bacon product(s) for both restaurant and individual consumer markets. 4-A Packing will peel and roast the New Mexico sourced green chile and add it to pre-cured bacon to further enhance the companys current product and service line.

funding_code: CF ARP EMERGENCY RURAL HEALTH CARE GRANTS - TRACK 1 & 2
naics_industry_sector: Health Care and Social Assistance (62)
project_announced_description: This Rural Development investment will be used to assist in recovery from the COVID-19 pandemic for Ben Archer Health Center in Deming, New Mexico. This is one of three grants, for four of the 11 Ben Archer health care facilities in southern New Mexico. This project will provide immediate relief to address economic conditions arising from the need to provide expanded COVID testing and vaccines to service area residents. The center will be reimbursed for some of the emergency expenses incurred from April 1, 2020, to September 30, 2021. The facility will also use these funds for budgeted medical supplies, personal protective equipment, COVID testing and vaccination, and laboratory equipment for the period of November 1, 2021, to April 30, 2023. Lastly, the center will purchase additional laptops with Electronic Health Record Telehealth Modules to increase their telehealth capabilities at this site and maintain the security of the current electronic health record system.

funding_code: CF ARP EMERGENCY RURAL HEALTH CARE GRANTS - TRACK 1 & 2
naics_industry_sector: Health Care and Social Assistance (62)
project_announced_description: This Rural Development investment will be used to assist in the recovery from the COVID-19 pandemic for the Ben Archer Health Center in Hatch and Columbus, New Mexico. This is one of three grants, for four of the 11 Ben Archer health care facilities in southern New Mexico. This project will provide immediate relief to address economic conditions arising from the pandemic emergency and expanded COVID testing and vaccines for patients residing in the service area. The center will be reimbursed for emergency expenses and lost revenue incurred during April 1, 2020 to September 30, 2021.The facility will also use these funds for budgeted medical supplies, personal protective equipment, COVID testing and vaccination, and laboratory equipment for the period of November 1, 2021 to April 30, 2023. Lastly, the Health Care Center will purchase additional laptops with Electronic Health Record Telehealth Modules to increase their telehealth capabilities at this site and maintain the security of the of the current electronic health record system.

funding_code: CF ARP EMERGENCY RURAL HEALTH CARE GRANTS - TRACK 1 & 2
naics_industry_sector: Health Care and Social Assistance (62)
project_announced_description: The Rural Development investment will be used to assist in recovery from the COVID-19 pandemic for Ben Archer Health Center in Truth or Consequences, New Mexico. This is one of three grants, for four of the 11 Ben Archer health care facilities in southern New Mexico. This project will provide immediate relief to address economic conditions arising from the pandemic emergency due to the need to provide expanded COVID testing and vaccines to service area patients. The center will be reimbursed for emergency expenses and lost revenue that was incurred throughout the pandemic during April 1, 2020 to September 30, 2021. The facility will also use these funds for budgeted medical supplies, personal protective equipment, COVID testing and vaccination, and laboratory equipment for the period of November 1, 2021 to April 30, 2023. Lastly, the Health Care Center will purchase additional laptops with Electronic Health Record Telehealth Modules to increase their telehealth capabilities at this site and maintain the security of the of the current electronic health record system.

funding_code: 306C WWD GRANT - WASTE AND/OR SEWAGE ONLY
naics_industry_sector: Utilities (22)

funding_code: (GRANT ONLY) 306C WASTE DISPOSAL ONLY (COLONIAS)
naics_industry_sector: Utilities (22)
project_announced_description: This Rural Development investment will be used to provide additional funding for the expansion of the waste water treatment plant in Anthony, New Mexico. This project will build a second circular concentric package plant, which will allow the original to be taken offline for cleaning and renovation. This funding will be used to upgrade the facility and extend the useful life of the structure and also remedy an issue with discharging to the river. Currently this issue has exceeded the limits set by the Environmental Protection Agency and has the potential to cause a health and sanitary problem to the community. Anthony Water & Sanitation District is a designated Colonias county, serving a persistent impoverished population. This project and partnership will provide a needed improvement to the communitys sewer services.

borrower_name: Lower Rio Grande Public Water Works Authority
funding_code: (GRANT ONLY) 306C WASTE DISPOSAL ONLY (COLONIAS)
naics_industry_sector: Utilities (22)
project_announced_description: This Rural Development investment will be used to assist the town of Newtons Water Works and Sewer Board with purchasing remotely read ("radio read") water meters. This investment will allow the board to closely track water consumption, reducing waste and more quickly alerting staff of a water leak in the system. This investment will also reduce the boards labor and transportation expenses in reading meters and will also help to ensure accuracy of the meter readings. This investment will benefit the 1,511 rural residents of the town.

funding_code: PERSISTENT POVERTY (COMB LOAN & GRANT) WASTE DISPOSAL ONLY
naics_industry_sector: Utilities (22)
project_announced_description: This Rural development investment will be used to provide additional Water and Environmental Program (WEP) Persistent Poverty funding for the expansion of the wastewater treatment plant in Anthony, New Mexico. This project will build a second circular concentric package plant, which will allow the original to be taken offline for cleaning and renovation. Our funding will not only upgrade the facility and prolong the life of the structure, but it will also remedy an issue with discharging to the river. Currently, this issue has exceeded the limits set by the Environmental Protection Agency and has the potential to cause a health and sanitary problem to the community. Anthony Water & Sanitation District is within a designated Colonias county, serving a persistent impoverished population. We are proud to partner with Anthony Water & Sanitation District to provide funding for this much needed improvement to their sewer services.

funding_code: (GRANT ONLY) PRE-DEVELOPMENT GRANTS - WATER ONLY
naics_industry_sector: Utilities (22)
project_announced_description: This Rural Developmental investment will be used to help in the planning and development phase of a potential improvement project in Leasburg, New Mexico located in the south-central part of the state. This small system currently encompasses 23 miles of distribution piping. Funding will be utilized for the preliminary engineering report, to evaluate the current system needs as far as replacement and upgrades. As well as help to identify inefficiencies within the system that may be causing environmental issues or failures for the customers attached.

program: Rural Energy for America Program Renewable Energy Systems and Energy Efficiency Improvement Loans and Grants
funding_code: RENEWABLE ENERGY SYSTEMS GRANT
naics_industry_sector: Manufacturing (31-33)
project_announced_description: This Rural Development investment will be used to assist New Mexico Wineries Inc. purchase and install a 204.47 kWh ground mounted solar array. New Mexico Wineries Inc. was established in 1981 and is headquartered in Deming, New Mexico. It owns several vineyards whose harvests produce grapes for their wine making operation. After the solar system is installed, it will generate more than 152.90 percent of the electricity that the business uses every year. The photovoltaic array will generate enough electricity to power 38 homes. This project falls under COVID-19 and Distressed Communities initiatives.

funding_code: CF ARP EMERGENCY RURAL HEALTH CARE GRANTS - TRACK 1 & 2
naics_industry_sector: Health Care and Social Assistance (62)
project_announced_description: This Rural Development investment will be used to purchase two ambulances for the Gila Regional Medical Center located in Silver City, New Mexico. Both ambulances will be equipped with the necessary medical gear making the units fully operational to provide emergency medical service to the three southwestern counties of New Mexico. The new emergency medical vehicles will replace older ambulances, which are near or past their useful effective service life. The old ambulances have become unreliable due to high usage, and mileage. Because of their age they require constant maintenance making them unreliable which places the publics safety at great risk. The new ambulances will play an important role to quickly give effective emergency medical service which in turn provides a safer community. The service area for the ambulances includes the communities of Bayard, Columbus, Deming, Hurley, Lordsburg, Reserve, Santa Clara, Silver City, and Virden located in Grant, Hidalgo, and Luna counties. This service area is almost 2,000 square miles larger than the states of Delaware Rhode Island combined.

funding_code: CF ARP EMERGENCY RURAL HEALTH CARE GRANTS - TRACK 1 & 2
naics_industry_sector: Other or Not Defined
naics_description: OTHER FIRE/RESCUE & PUBLIC SAFETY RELATED SERVICES
project_announced_description: This Rural Development investment will be used to purchase updated medical equipment. The purchase of the equipment will help Gila Regional Medical Center located in Silver City, New Mexico provide better medical service to the rural residents of this area of the state. The new equipment will include anesthesia machines, ultrasound machines, ventilators, surgical tables, surgical suite lights, a washer for sterile processing, a bipap breathing machine system, a refrigerator, a neo-Vectra-e-stim unit with laser, range, and computers on wheels for documentation at patients bedside. The Gila Regional Medical Center needs the new equipment to replace old and obsolete equipment, which are near or past their useful effective life. Due to the age of the equipment, it is difficult to find parts to repair these pieces of equipment. With the onset of COVID-19, this caused more stress on the already obsolete equipment and in some cases the Medical Center did not have adequate equipment to meet the needs of the hospital. The low reliability of the older equipment places the public safety at great risk. The new equipment plays an important role in the community by enabling the medical center to quickly respond to the needs of its patients. The Gila Regional Medical Center services the communities of Bayard, Columbus, Deming, Hurley, Lordsburg, Reserve, Santa Clara, Silver City, and Virden in Grant, Hidalgo and Luna located in southwest New Mexico.

project_announced_description: This Rural Development investment will be used to help BCA Medical purchase and install spray foam insulation and LED lighting. BCA Medical is a pediatric care center in Ruidoso, New Mexico. After the energy efficiency improvements are completed, the business will see $1,412 in savings on their annual electric bill and will replace 31,726 kWh (50.92 percent) per year. This savings is enough electricity to power two homes. The purpose of REAP funding program is to assist farmers, ranchers, and rural small businesses in developing renewable energy systems, and in making energy-efficiency improvements to their operations.

funding_code: RENEWABLE ENERGY SYSTEMS GRANT
naics_industry_sector: Retail Trade (44-45)
naics_description: SUPERMARKETS AND OTHER GROCERY (EXCEPT CONVENIENCE) STORES
project_announced_description: This Rural Development investment will be used to purchase and install an 84.15 kilowatt (kW) direct current (DC) canopy mounted solar array. Established in 1988, Major Market LLC, is a native-owned, 45 percent women-controlled family business in Zuni, New Mexico. The business provides food and groceries to the local and outlying areas of Zuni. After the solar system is installed, the business will see $8,658.00 savings in their annual electric bill. It will generate 150,529 kilowatt-hours (kWh) of electricity which is more than 86.93 percent of the electricity the business uses every year. The photovoltaic array will generate enough electricity to power 13 homes.

funding_code: NATIVE AMERICAN TRIBES COMMUNITY FACILITY GRANTS
naics_industry_sector: Educational Services (61)
naics_description: ALL OTHER MISCELLANEOUS SCHOOLS AND INSTRUCTION
project_announced_description: This Rural Development investment will be used to purchase laboratory infrastructure, equipment and accessories that follow U.S. Environmental Project Agency regulations for the Navajo Technical University (NTU), an educational institution located in Crownpoint, New Mexico. This project will benefit NTUs Chinle Arizona Campus which is located within the Din Community also known as the Navajo Nation. The investment will be used to purchase certified fume hoods, chemical and resistant bench spaces, shelves, tables to place the analytical equipment and secure safety cabinets. NTU has provided science and technology curriculum since 1985. The university is providing this state-of-art technology to the students of the Navajo Nation based upon the Din culture and traditions. The campus is available to all Native American students.

The business will see a savings of $5,545 in its annual electric bill and generate 43,263 kWh of electricity which is more than 132 percent of the electricity the business uses every year, which is enough electricity to power four homes.

funding_code: ELEC SECTION 4 TREASURY RATE - PERSISTENT POVERTY
naics_industry_sector: Utilities (22)
project_announced_description: This Rural Development investment will be used to connect 383 consumers, and build 30 miles of line. Roosevelt County Electric is headquartered in Portales, New Mexico, and serving on average 6,114 consumers through 2,846 miles of line through four counties in eastern New Mexico.

funding_code: DLT CONGRESSIONALLY DIRECTED SPENDING - GRANTS
naics_industry_sector: Utilities (22)
project_announced_description: This Rural Development investment will be used to equip additional classrooms for the Health Education and Access to Learning (HEAL) Project in rural New Mexico. The HEAL Project will deliver distance learning to rural and exceptionally rural individuals in Dona Ana, Sierra, Otero and Luna Counties in New Mexico. The HEAL Project will benefit an estimated 96,630 people in southern New Mexico.

funding_code: DLT CONGRESSIONALLY DIRECTED SPENDING - GRANTS
naics_industry_sector: Utilities (22)
project_announced_description: This Rural Development investment will equip 104 of New Mexicos public and tribal libraries with high quality computer equipment, soundproof booths, Early Childhood Literacy "Train the Trainer" curriculum and Adult Literacy curriculum, including English as a Second Language, basic mathematics, basic computer training, and citizenship. This project will benefit the 1,626,890 residents served by the libraries in 31 counties.

funding_code: PILOT BROADBAND 100% GRANT- RBS REDG SUB ACCOUNT SEC. 762- GRANT
naics_industry_sector: Utilities (22)
project_announced_description: This Rural Development investment will be used to deploy a fiber-to-the-premise network. This network will connect 606 people, eight businesses, 34 farms and two public schools to high-speed internet in Cibola and McKinley counties. Continental will make high-speed internet affordable by participating in the Federal Communications Commissions Emergency Broadband Benefit and Affordable Connectivity Plans. This project will serve the Laguna Pueblo, the Acoma Pueblo, and the Acoma Off-Reservation Trust Land tribal entities as well as socially vulnerable communities in Cibola and McKinley counties.

funding_code: PILOT BROADBAND 100% GRANT- RBS REDG SUB ACCOUNT SEC. 762- GRANT
naics_industry_sector: Utilities (22)
project_announced_description: This Rural Development investment will be used to deploy a fiber-to-the-premises (FTTP) network to connect people,businesses and farms to high-speed internet in Chaves, Colfax, De Baca, Guadalupe, Harding, Lincoln, San Miguel, Socorro, Torrance and Union counties. E.N.M.R. will make high-speed internet affordable by offering price plans that match the pricing offered to all other FTTP Cooperative members. All three plans will include free Wi-Fi service. This project will serve socially vulnerable communities in Colfax, De Baca, Guadalupe, San Miguel and Socorro counties.

funding_code: PILOT BROADBAND GRANT

project_announced_description: This Rural Development investment will be used to help expand Lewis Gardens LLC customer base beyond San Juan County but statewide and nationally. Lewis Gardens in Bloomfield, New Mexico is typically known for growing fresh green chile, roasting and selling by the bushel. They are now taking their roasted green chile in and freeze drying it to expand their current market base. This allows for much longer shelf life and less space needed without being refrigerated, very reasonable shipping costs and packaging materials.

funding_code: RBCS ENTERPRISE GRANTS
naics_industry_sector: Professional, Scientific, and Technical Services (54)
project_announced_description: This Rural Development investment will be used to help National Mainstreet Center Inc. for research and development of a small business resiliency audit tool and resource pilot in Tucumcari, Lovington and Las Vegas, three rural Main Street communities in New Mexico. The project will benefit rural small business owners by helping them recognize the challenges they face, providing direct access to tools and resources to resolve those issues, and increase jobs in each of the targeted communities. The resources developed from this project will be implemented in many more rural Mainstreet communities throughout New Mexico.

funding_code: RBCS ENTERPRISE NATIVE AMERICAN GRANT
naics_industry_sector: Public Administration (92)
naics_description: AMERICAN INDIAN AND ALASKA NATIVE TRIBAL GOVERNMENTS
project_announced_description: This Rural Development investment will be used to offer business development opportunities to members of the Pueblo of Pojoaque via "The Answer is Indigenous Project". This project will provide training and support for creative entrepreneurs, to include those participating in the local farmers market and for the food handling entrepreneurs. This project is intended to create more sustainable venues for sales and create part and/or full-time employment for program participants.

borrower_name: NORTH CENTRAL NEW MEXICO ECONOMIC DEVELOPMENT DISTRICT
funding_code: CF TAT GRANT (SECTION 6006)
naics_industry_sector: Other or Not Defined
project_announced_description: This Rural Development investment will be used to provide technical assistance and grant writing support to an estimated 15 high need rural communities in the North Central New Mexico Economic Development District. The eight county areas, include Colfax, Las Alamos, Mora, Rio Arriba, San Miguel, northern Sandoval, Santa Fe and Taos counties. By partnering with member communities, the district will utilize this program to assist with community and economic development projects and initiatives.

funding_code: NATIVE AMERICAN TRIBES COMMUNITY FACILITY GRANTS
naics_industry_sector: Other or Not Defined
project_announced_description: This Rural Development investment will be used to purchase needed equipment. Institute of American Indian Art (IAIA) an educational institution located near Santa Fe, New Mexico will purchase solar panels for its Welcome Center, Performing Arts Building, Fitness Center and installing an EV charging station. IAIA is a member of the Climate Action Task Force to reduce their carbon footprint. The purchase and installation of the solar panels will assist them in decreasing their electricity consumption and in meeting its goal to improve the environment. IAIA is one of the colleges covered by the Equity in Education Land-Grant Status Act of 1994. The school provides a national center of research, training, and scholarship for Native Americans who are interested in Native American art and culture. Most of the population attending the college is Native American; however, the campus is open to all worldwide.

borrower_name: Canada de los Alamos Mutual Domestic Water Consumers and Mutual Sewage Works Association
funding_code: (GRANT ONLY) ECWAG - APPROPRIATED $1,000,000 LIMIT
naics_industry_sector: Utilities (22)
project_announced_description: This Rural Development investment will be used to purchase a well for the small water association of Canada de Los Alamos. Recent extreme drought conditions made it impossible to access water locally, so for two years the community was forced to haul water. Construction of a new well will provide potable water to the rural community, help alleviate health and sanitary concerns, and meet requirements set by the New Mexico Environment Department.

funding_code: (WWA PROGRAM AREA) SOLID WASTE GRANT
naics_industry_sector: Utilities (22)
project_announced_description: This Rural Development investment will be used to provide technical assistance and training opportunities to rural Native American Pueblo communities located within northern New Mexico. The goal for this project by the New Mexico Recycling Coalition is to provide the needed training to reduce the solid waste stream by focusing on proven methods of sustainable materials management. This includes waste characterization studies also known as waste audits or waste assessments.

funding_code: (WWA PROGRAM AREA) SOLID WASTE GRANT
naics_industry_sector: Utilities (22)
project_announced_description: This Rural Development investment will be used to leverage the composting expertise of contractor Reunity Resources using biochar production capacities that are being built in New Mexico. Biochar is produced byheating biomass in the total or partial absence of oxygen. The grant will ultimately develop an on-farm/on-ranch composting program focusing on communities surrounding the transfer station in community of Wagon Mound in northeast New Mexico. The certification for this composting program will be provided by the New Mexico Recycling Coalition (NMRC) and New Mexico Environment Department (NMED) to implement an education, certification, and demonstration program.

funding_code: GUARANTEED B&I 3% FEE LOAN
naics_industry_sector: Accommodation and Food Services (72)
project_announced_description: This Rural Development investment will be used to refinance a real estate contract on a recreational vehicle park in Truth or Consequences, New Mexico. The RJ RV Park is located close to downtown Truth or Consequences and sits on a 4.64-acre site which has 47 RV spaces. Each space has a full hookup to city water and sewer. The spaces also have and 30 and 50 AMP electricity hook ups to accommodate the different electrical needs of the recreational vehicles renting the spaces. The park has both back in and pull thru sites with some extra-long spaces available for big rigs. The RJ RV Park also has a 1,775 square foot Community Building which includes a full-service kitchen, showers, and restrooms for guests. This building is also used for special activities.

borrower_name: MIDDLE RIO GRANDE ECONOMIC DEVELOPMENT A
funding_code: SECD BUSINESS OPPORTUNITY GRANT - SECD
naics_industry_sector: Public Administration (92)
project_announced_description: This Rural Development investment will be used to assist Middle Rio Grande Economic Development Association contract with Community Economic Laboratory (CEL). CEL is a private not-for-profit think tank to conduct the final strategic planning phase of the economic recovery project for Sierra and Socorro Counties. The project will develop the necessary steps to assist in the recovery of the economies for the region by leading with remote work opportunities, regional job fairs, soft skills training and additional economic development activities.

program: Rural Energy for America Program Renewable Energy Systems and Energy Efficiency Improvement Loans and Grants
borrower_name: ILABEN K. PATEL DBA SAN MIGUEL INN
funding_code: MAND.ENERGY EFFIC IMPROV GRANTS UNDER $20,000
naics_industry_sector: Accommodation and Food Services (72)
project_announced_description: This Rural Development investment will be used to help Ilaben K. Patel dba San Miguel Inn purchase and install various energy efficient equipment at the 41-unit motel located in Socorro, New Mexico. The funding will be used to install 40 wall mounted HVAC units, LED lighting upgrades, 41 mini-refrigerators and televisions. The improvements will save $14,922 in the motels annual electric bill. The savings will replace 114,787.64 kWh or 70.89percent electricity used by the motel every year. This is enough electricity to power 15 homes.

funding_code: CF ARP EMERGENCY RURAL HEALTH CARE GRANTS - TRACK 1 & 2
naics_industry_sector: Health Care and Social Assistance (62)
project_announced_description: This Rural Development investment will be used to purchase an ambulance for the city of Socorro fire department. During the pandemic, the current ambulances were being utilized not only for patient transport but also to provide mobile testing for COVID-19. The citys ambulances were also utilized to assist in administering the COVID vaccine to homebound residents. The increased use during the pandemic advanced the wear on these vehicles. As a result, a new transport ambulance is needed to allow the fire department to expand needed rescue and health services to the 8,300 residents of the city of Socorro.

funding_code: BUSINESS & INDUSTRY GUARANTEED LOAN - 1%
naics_industry_sector: Accommodation and Food Services (72)
project_announced_description: This Rural Development investment will be used to refinance debt, and financing of fees to the owners of the historic Sagebrush Inn, in Taos, New Mexico. Known as, "The Inn" the historic hotel opened 91 years ago in 1931 and offered at that time 13 guestrooms that became known for its authentic Southwest dcor. Today, "The Inn" is still known for its dcor and now offers 156 guestrooms with wi-fi, swimming pool, spa tub, restaurant and laundry services. Over the years numerous celebrities have stayed at the Inn. Also, "The Inn" had several major movies shot in and around the property. Most notable were the movies Easy Rider and Twins. By refinancing the debt with a B&I guaranteed loan the hotel will continue in business and a 150 jobs will be saved.

funding_code: RBCS ENTERPRISE GRANTS
naics_industry_sector: Health Care and Social Assistance (62)
project_announced_description: This Rural Development investment will be used to purchase equipment to assist three small, minority and women-owned businesses in Peasco, New Mexico. MAS Comunidad, a non-profit organization, will purchase required restaurant equipment to stay in compliance with Taos County Health Department. In addition, Mas Comunidad will purchase refrigeration units to upgrade the only existing grocery store in Taos, New Mexico.

funding_code: SECD RB DEV ENTERPRISE GRANT
naics_industry_sector: Other or Not Defined
project_announced_description: This Rural Development investment is being used to help the Town of Taos purchase bottling and canning equipment to be leased to Rolling Still Bros LLC. This is a rural, woman-owned, small business in Taos New Mexico that manufactures hand-crafted spirits. The grant will help Rolling Still Bros meet its growing customer demand, and allow the business to expand nationally and enter the new ready to drink market. This equipment will save 14 jobs and create 14 new positions. The saving and creation of new jobs is extremely important because a 2019 data report from City-Data.com shows 27.3 percent of the 6,000 residents living in the Town of Taos are living in poverty. Read more: http://www.city-data.com/city/Taos-New-Mexico.html

program: Rural Energy for America Program Renewable Energy Systems and Energy Efficiency Improvement Loans and Grants
borrower_name: STUART M. WILDE DBA WILD EARTH LLAMA ADV
funding_code: MAND. RENEW ENERFY SYSTEMS GRANTS UNDER $20,000
naics_industry_sector: Arts, Entertainment, and Recreation (71)
naics_description: ALL OTHER AMUSEMENT AND RECREATION INDUSTRIES
project_announced_description: This Rural Development investment will be used to help Stuart Wilde doing business as Wild Earth Llama Adventures purchase and install a 12 kW ground mounted solar array with a 10 kW battery backup. Wild Earth Llama Adventures is a sole proprietor rural small business involved in ecotourism and outdoor adventures established in 1993 in Questa, New Mexico. After the solar system is installed, the business will see $997.00 savings in their annual electric bill of the eligible project costs. It will generate 20,502 kilowatt-hours of electricity which is more than 368 percent of the electricity the business uses every year. The photovoltaic array will generate enough electricity to power one home.

program: Rural Energy for America Program Renewable Energy Systems and Energy Efficiency Improvement Loans and Grants
borrower_name: DEBORAH GRAVES DBA CHILI LINE DEPOT
funding_code: MAND. RENEW ENERFY SYSTEMS GRANTS UNDER $20,000
naics_industry_sector: Accommodation and Food Services (72)
project_announced_description: This Rural Development investment will be used to help Deborah Graves doing business as Chili Line Depot purchase and install a 14.4kW roof-mounted solar array. The Chili Line Depot is a family-owned restaurant and lodging rural small business in Tres Piedras, Taos County, New Mexico. After the solar system is installed, the business will see $7,280.00 savings in their annual electric bill. It will generate 26,645 kWh of electricity which is more than 51.24 percent of the electricity the business uses every year. The photovoltaic array will generate enough electricity to power two homes.

funding_code: REAP-MANDATORY RENEW ENERGY SYST GRANTS
naics_industry_sector: Manufacturing (31-33)
naics_description: CUT STONE AND STONE PRODUCT MANUFACTURING
project_announced_description: This Rural Development investment will be used to help New Mexico Travertine Inc. purchase and install a 62.50 kW solar array. New Mexico Travertine Inc. quarries and fabricates natural stone to produce several different products such as countertops. After the solar system is installed, the business will see $46,904.00 savings in their annual electric bill. It will generate 240,799 kilowatt-hours of electricity which is about 87.28 percent of the electricity the business uses every year. The photovoltaic array will generate enough electricity to power 22 homes. The purpose of REAP funding program is to assist farmers, ranchers, and rural small businesses in developing renewable energy systems, and in making energy-efficiency improvements to their operations.

program: Rural Energy for America Program Renewable Energy Systems and Energy Efficiency Improvement Loans and Grants
funding_code: REAP-MANDATORY RENEW ENERGY SYST GRANTS
naics_industry_sector: Manufacturing (31-33)
project_announced_description: This Rural Development investment will be used to help Sisneros Bros. MFG. LLC purchase and install a 120.96 kW Carport mounted solar array. Sisneros Bros. MFG. LLC is a third and fourth generation family-owned stainless steel duct manufacturing business established in 1987 in Belen, New Mexico. After the solar system is installed, the business will see $14,905.00 savings in their annual electric bill. It will generate 200,039 kilowatt-hours of electricity which is more than 120.79 percent of the electricity the business uses every year. The photovoltaic array will generate enough electricity to power 18 homes. The purpose of REAP funding program is to assist farmers, ranchers, and rural small businesses in developing renewable energy systems, and in making energy-efficiency improvements to their operations.
