funding_code: PERSISTENT POVERTY RBCS BUSINESS ENTERPRISE GRANT
naics_industry_sector: Arts, Entertainment, and Recreation (71)
naics_description: ALL OTHER AMUSEMENT AND RECREATION INDUSTRIES
project_announced_description: This Rural Development investment will be used to build five cohesive and self-sustained tourism businesses located directly within Gallinas Canyon located in San Miguel County in northeastern New Mexico. Project will assist the Gallinas Rural Tourism Project and guide members of the Gallinas/El Porvenir community in developing better business practices. The participants will receive training in basic business finances including LLC development and branding, plus hospitality and food safety training. This project will create two jobs and save three jobs in this high unemployment area of northern New Mexico.

funding_code: FY22 CONGRESSIONALLY DIRECTED SPENDING
naics_industry_sector: Manufacturing (31-33)
project_announced_description: This Rural Development investment will be used to construct a building for the East Mountain Food Pantry in Tijeras, New Mexico. The facility will be a 5,500 square foot prefabricated metal building which is designed to facilitate the customers, allowing them to drive around the facility to complete registration and food pick-up. The delivery area is independent from facility entry and registration and pick-up. It will be covered and can accommodate a tractor trailer. The processing floor is surrounded by the office, conference room, restrooms, and storage areas. This larger storage area will accommodate multiple storage options. The floor is designed for different arrangements and predicated on a grocery bag assembly line. This project will enable East Mountain Food Pantry Inc. to efficiently provide life-sustaining food safely for community households who struggle with food insecurity.

Heritage Dairy LLC is located in Clovis, Curry County, New Mexico. After the solar system is installed, the business will see a significant savings of $53,690 in their annual electric bill. The solar photovoltaic system will generate 1,376,163 kilowatt hours (kWh) of electricity which is more than 115 percent of the electricity the business uses every year. The photovoltaic array will generate enough electricity to power 127 homes.

program: Food Supply Chain Guaranteed Loan Program
funding_code: FOOD SUPPLY CHAIN (FSC)
naics_industry_sector: Manufacturing (31-33)
project_announced_description: This Rural Development investment will be used to help offset the costs of purchasing a new building. BSREH LLC is a holding company for the new Diamond Onions facility located in Santa Teresa, New Mexico. Diamond Onions processes whole peeled onions for customers throughout the United States. Their Dallas facility contains peeling machines and is operating at capacity. The new facility under the name Oro Onions LLC will allow for the additional peeling lines, storage, and logistical efficiencies as it will be located closer to many local growers. The new facility will allow Diamond Onions to take advantage of additional market opportunities and is projecting to create 32 new jobs.

funding_code: RBCS ENTERPRISE GRANTS
naics_industry_sector: Manufacturing (31-33)
project_announced_description: This Rural Development investment will be used to purchase food manufacturing equipment including a walk-in freezer, bag labeling machine and a chip bagging machine by non-profit Cruces Creatives. Once purchased the equipment will be leased to Backyard Farms, a rural small business located in Vado, New Mexico in southern Dona Ana County. The goal of the project is to allow Backyard Farms to expand its freeze-drying business by improving production and distribution of fruits and vegetables. The expansion provides financial growth for small farmers as well as access to healthier and nutritious food for underserved and vulnerable populations in food deserts. 12 jobs will be created.

program: Rural Energy for America Program Energy Audits and Renewable Energy Development Grants
borrower_name: REGENTS OF NEW MEXICO STATE UNIVERSITY
funding_code: REAP ENERGY AUDIT RECIPIENT
naics_industry_sector: Educational Services (61)
project_announced_description: This Rural Development investment will be used to conduct approximately 12 energy audits for rural small businesses and agricultural producers throughout the state of New Mexico. These audits will provide analysis to make energy-efficiency improvements to these operations and/or install renewable energy systems.

program: Rural Energy for America Technical Assistance Grant Program
borrower_name: REGENTS OF NEW MEXICO STATE UNIVERSITY
funding_code: REAP IRA TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE GRANTS
naics_industry_sector: Educational Services (61)
project_announced_description: This Rural Development investment will be used throughout the state of New Mexico to provide technical assistance to 18 rural small businesses and agricultural producers. The technical assistance that Regents of New Mexico State University will provide will be energy assessments, audits, and technical reports; as well as establish a library of best practices and materials used to assist future NM REAP applicants. It will prioritize projects based on the REAP Technical Assistance Grant (TAG) program objectives, i.e., distressed or disadvantage communities, underutilized technologies, or grant requests of $20,000 or less. The purpose of this funding program is to assist farmers, ranchers, and rural small businesses in making and submitting a complete REAP application. Regents of New Mexico State University is in Dona Ana County, NM which falls within an RPN Community.

program: Rural Energy for America Technical Assistance Grant Program
funding_code: REAP IRA TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE GRANTS
naics_industry_sector: Professional, Scientific, and Technical Services (54)
project_announced_description: This Rural Development investment will be used throughout the state of New Mexico to provide technical assistance for 10 to18 rural small businesses and agricultural producers applying to the Renewable Energy for America Program (REAP). The technical assistance will provide energy assessments, audits, and technical reports; as well as assist with preparing reports, planning, completion of environmental reports and REAP applications. It will prioritize projects based on the REAP Technical Assistance Grant (TAG) program objectives, i.e., Distressed or Disadvantage Communities, underutilized technologies, or grant requests of $20,000 or less. The purpose of this funding program is to assist farmers, ranchers, and rural small businesses in making and submitting a complete REAP application. Sustainable Engineering, LLC is headquartered in Dona Ana County, NM a Rural Partners Network (RPN) community.

funding_code: LAMP VALUE ADDED PRODUCER GRANT MANDATORY
naics_industry_sector: Other Services (except Public Administration) (81)
project_announced_description: This Rural Development investment will allow 4-A Packing the opportunity to grow and expand its market and distribution area. Located in is in Deming, Luna County New Mexico 4-A Packing will use the grant funding working to expand its processing of fresh chile into freeze dried green chile stew packs. By doing so, the business will be able to expand to new markets because it will be creating a longer shelf life, which will allow a more cost-effective distribution to a larger area. This project will create 4 new jobs and will increase this companys customer base.

funding_code: FY22 CONGRESSIONALLY DIRECTED SPENDING
naics_industry_sector: Other or Not Defined
naics_description: OTHER FIRE/RESCUE & PUBLIC SAFETY RELATED SERVICES
project_announced_description: This Rural Development investment will be used to pay for the feasibility, preliminary architecture report, and environmental reports in preparation for the construction of a Public Safety Complex in Sunland Park, New Mexico. The Public Safety Complex will correct a severely underserved area by placing the station near the center of the city. The new fire station will bring the area into compliance with National Fire Protection Associations recommendations of the 240-second travel time to its response district. When built the complex will house two front-line, first responding firefighting apparatus, including a Quint 3. A Quint 3 is a combination pumper or quint is a fire truck that serves the dual purpose of an engine and a ladder truck. "Quintuple" refers to the five functions that a quint provides - pump, water tank, fire hose, aerial device, and ground ladders. The new facility will house 12 permanently assigned personnel on a 24-hour rotating shifts. It will also house the police headquarters and a prisoner holding facility. The Public Safety Complex will correct a severely underserved area by placing the station near the center of the city.The new fire station will bring the area into compliance with National Fire Protection Associations recommendations of the 240-second travel time to its response district. When built the complex will house two front-line, first responding firefighting apparatus, including a Quint 3. borrower_name: Dona Ana Mutual Domestic Water Consumers Association
funding_code: PERSISTENT POVERTY (COMB LOAN & GRANT) WASTE DISPOSAL ONLY
naics_industry_sector: Utilities (22)
project_announced_description: This Rural Development investment will be used to add funding to the original project funding of a loan of $4,226,000.00 and a grant of $6,829,965.00 made in 2019 to expand the Doa Ana Mutual Domestic Water Consumers Association (DAMDWCA) wastewater collection system. The expansion of the wastewater collection system will allow additional customers in a nearby subdivision to connect to the sewer system. At the same time the larger capacity of services for existing users will be expanded. Located in southern New Mexico the DAMDWCA has been a USDA Rural Development customer since the late 1970s and has continued to utilize USDA RD funding for the ever-growing community they serve.

project_announced_description: This Rural Development investment will be used to rehabilitate the city of Jal, New Mexicos existing wastewater treatment facility. The project will also see the construction of additional facilities to handle disinfection process, new influent pump, equalization basin and roughly 130 linear ft. of new piping. In addition, construction of new headworks, a secondary treatment facility, a solids management and disposal facilities including sludge holding tank and dewatering facility will be completed. Lastly, new piping will be installed to connect to existing effluent discharge piping. With this project, the city of Jal will be able to meet all the requirements of the Corrective Action Plan put into place as a result of deficiencies of the current wastewater treatment system. This combined effort on behalf of the State of New Mexico and USDA Rural Development, will allow the city of Jal to maintain their effluent Discharge Permit issued from the New Mexico Environmental Department.

project_announced_description: This Rural Development investment will be used to purchase and install a biomass system which will utilize cow manure to produce biogas. Brand West Biogas LLC is in Lovington, New Mexico, which is adjacent to the Brand West Dairy which has 8,600 dairy cows. The manure from the dairy and participating diaries will be used to produce the biogas. When the biomass system is completed, the project will produce 113,335 million BTUs of renewable natural gas annually. The business is a special purpose entity created to develop, own, and operate anaerobic dairy digesters to generate renewable biomethane for sale to Compressed Natural Gas fueling stations in California.

project_announced_description: This Rural Development investment will be used to purchase an existing La Quinta Inn & Suites motel, located in Ruidoso Downs, New Mexico. The motel is a single three-story building which encompasses 38,455 square feet with 63 guest rooms. The motel is complete with a breakfast dining area, indoor pool, indoor whirlpool, fitness room, lobby workstation, market pantry, and a guest laundry room. The borrower Luxor Hospitality, LLC. is a New Mexico limited liability company established on July 27, 2022 specifically for the purchase and operation of the motel. The motel is strategically located because it supports the tourism and leisure demand industry in the area including destinations to; Ski Apache, Ruidoso Downs Race Track, and Inn of the Mountain Gods Resort & Casino. The funding of this project is an example how USDA Rural Development supports the recreation economy in rural New Mexico by growing and maintaining a healthy recreation sector by supporting entrepreneurship and small business growth. The funding of this project will save 21 jobs.

project_announced_description: This Rural Development investment will be used to purchase much need vehicles for Navajo Technical University (NTU) an educational institution located in Crownpoint, New Mexico located within the Dine Community (Navajo Nation). The financial support is being used to purchase a new 35 custom-built RV mobile veterinary spay and neuter freightliner unit. This equipment will enable NTU to provide needed veterinary animal surgery, animal wellness visits, and veterinary animal education on the Navajo Nation Eastern Agency communities. NTU provides a state-of-art technology to the Navajo Nation based upon the Dine culture and traditions. Navajo Technical University is available to all Native American students.

project_announced_description: This Rural Development investment will be used to purchase equipment for several small businesses in Mora, New Mexico by the Mora County Economic Development Corporation (Mora EDC). Mora EDC will then lease the equipment such as welding gear for Diamond A Welding, embroidery equipment for MAD Embroidery, a refrigerator and freezer for Mora Valley Ranch Supply and a stove and HVAC units for Tiale Restaurant. naics_industry_sector: Public Administration (92)
project_announced_description: This Rural Development investment will be used to replace an aging brush/wildland fire truck for the Arch Volunteer Fire Department located in eastern New Mexico. This modern fire truck will enable volunteer firefighters to effectively execute the mutual aid agreement between the municipalities of Portales, Causey, Dora, Elida, Floyd, Roosevelt County, and the fire departments of Arch and Milnesand. Abrush/wildland fire truckis a fire engine specifically designed to assist in fighting wildfires in rough terrain by transporting firefighters to the scene and providing them with the water and equipment needed to fight the fire. Ultimately, this new fire truck will provide better fire prevention, suppression, general fire-fighting activities while continuously providing available emergency related medical services.

funding_code: REAP IRA RES GRANT $20K AND LESS (FY 23)

naics_description: OTHER ACTIVITIES RELATED TO REAL ESTATE
project_announced_description: This Rural Development investment is being made to TKL LLC dba Pecos River Cabins, for the purchase and installation of a 4.8 kilowatt (kW) and a 3.2 kW solar array. TKL LLC dba Pecos River Cabins, is located in Pecos, San Miguel County, New Mexico. After the solar systems are installed, the business will see $1,282 savings in their annual electric bill. It will generate 14,356 kilowatt-hours of electricity which is more than 130 percent of the electricity the business uses every year. The photovoltaic array will generate enough electricity to power one home.

These new vehicles will enable firefighters and emergency services personnel to immediately respond to incidents within the community. This project promotes fire prevention, suppression, and general fire-fighting activities while continuously providing available emergency related medical services.

funding_code: FY22 CONGRESSIONALLY DIRECTED SPENDING
naics_industry_sector: Health Care and Social Assistance (62)
project_announced_description: This Rural Development investment will be used to construct a community center. The new facility will replace the current community center which doesnt comply with current energy standards, life safety codes, and accessibility guidelines. The functionally of the current community center does not accommodate the current needs of the San Felipe Pueblo community. The new Community Center will be used for community functions for all ages, including providing WIFI for students, classrooms where native language courses will be taught, along with intergenerational cultural sessions with the youth and elders of the Pueblo focusing on preserving the Keresan language which is spoken by those living at San Felipe Pueblo.

funding_code: FY22 CONGRESSIONALLY DIRECTED SPENDING
naics_industry_sector: Public Administration (92)
project_announced_description: This Rural Development investment will be used by the Village of Cuba Volunteer Fire Department to replace its aging fire engine pumper. The Village of Cuba is located at the base of the Jemez Mountains in northern New Mexico, and the new modern and fire engine will enable volunteer firefighters to effectively provide better fire service to the 635 residents of this mountain village community. The fire engine will also be dispatched to provide emergency and fire project along a 100-mile stretch of U.S. Highway 550, which is a heavily traveled highway connecting the northwest part of the state to central New Mexico. It is expected the fire apparatus will see heavy use because of the anticipated 400 emergency calls annually.

program: Rural Energy for America Program Renewable Energy Systems and Energy Efficiency Improvement Loans and Grants
funding_code: REAP IRA RES GRANT $20K AND LESS (FY 23)
naics_industry_sector: Agriculture, Forestry, Fishing and Hunting (11)
naics_description: OTHER VEGETABLE (EXCEPT POTATO) AND MELON FARMING
project_announced_description: This Rural Development investment is being used to assist Chelenzo Enterprises LLC purchase and install a 6.66 kilowatt (kW) solar photovoltaic system and a 10.6 kilowat hours (kWh) battery storage system at this farm. Chelenzo Enterprises, located in Cerrillos, Santa Fe County, New Mexico is a unique farming operation where guests are given an opportunity to experience a working farm in action. After the solar power system is installed, the business will see $1,427 savings in their annual electric bill. The solar array will generate 13,370 kWhs of electricity which is more than 140 percent of the electricity the business uses every year. This is enough electricity to power one average sized home.

funding_code: NATIVE AMERICAN TRIBES COMMUNITY FACILITY GRANTS
naics_industry_sector: Other or Not Defined
project_announced_description: This Rural Development investment will be used to purchase Electric Vehicle (EV) charging stations for the parking areas and installing 382 solar panels to power the Academic Building located at the Institute of American Indian Arts (IAIA) campus an educational institution located near Santa Fe, New Mexico. The solar panels will produce 248,052 kilowatt hours (kwh) of electricity which will assist IAIA in decreasing its electricity consumption and meeting the schools goal to reduce its carbon footprint. IAIA is a member of the Climate Action Task Force (CATF) which documents, informs, and supports the climate action efforts of tribal nations and organizations. IAIA is one of the colleges covered by the Equity in Education Land-Grant Status Act of 1994. The school is a national center of research, training, and scholarship for Native Americans who are interested in Native art and culture. The majority of the population attending the college is Native American; however, the campus is open to all worldwide.

funding_code: (GRANT ONLY) 306C  WATER ONLY (COLONIAS)
naics_industry_sector: Utilities (22)
project_announced_description: This Rural Development investment will be used to rehabilitate the city of Truth or Consequences water distribution system by replacing old water lines. Approximately 57 percent of the existing water system is 50 years old and has high water pressures, which have led to extensive line breakage, making operation and maintenance continuous and costly. In recent years, the system has experienced an extreme amount of water loss and outages to critical need facilities such as hospitals, schools, and assisted living homes. This project will replace more than 13,000 linear feet of existing water pipe with larger diameter sized pipe and include the installation of new meter cans and water service lines.

funding_code: (LOAN ONLY) WATER ONLY
naics_industry_sector: Utilities (22)
project_announced_description: The Rural Development loan and grant investment will be used to rehabilitate the city of Truth or Consequences water distribution system by replacing old water lines. Approximately 57% of the existing water system is 50-years old and has high water pressures that have led to extensive line breakage, which make operation and maintenance continuous and costly. In recent years the system has experienced an extreme amount of water loss and outages to some critical need facilities such as; hospitals, schools, and assisted living homes. This project will replace more than 13,000 linear feet of existing water pipe with larger diameter sized pipe as well as the installation of new meter cans and water service lines.

funding_code: PERSISTENT POVERTY RBCS BUSINESS ENTERPRISE GRANT
naics_industry_sector: Health Care and Social Assistance (62)
project_announced_description: This Rural Development investment will be used to allow Mas Comunidad, a non-profit organization in Peasco, New Mexico purchase and then lease much needed equipment for four small businesses located in this small northern New Mexico community. By doing so Mas Comunidad is helping with expansion, growth, safety, and security for these businesses.The funds will be used to purchase; hay cutting, raking, and baling equipment for the Roybal Ranch.Refrigerators, freezers, food preparation tables, burners and ovens will be purchased for La Jicarita Harvest a roadside food vendor located on State Road 75.El Ya Merito a restaurant in Peasco will lease from Mas Communidad; refrigerators, freezers, food preparation tables, burners, and ovens to help its operation.Travelers Service Station in Peasco as will lease a new tire changer, balancer, compressor, and upgrade doors and gates for the business.The equipment, safety upgrades and improved security measures will help save 9 jobs and create an additional eleven new positions in this persistent poverty, rural community.

program: Rural Energy for America Program Renewable Energy Systems and Energy Efficiency Improvement Loans and Grants
funding_code: REAP IRA RES GRANT UNRESTRICTED (FY 22/23)
naics_industry_sector: Accommodation and Food Services (72)
project_announced_description: This Rural Development investment will be used to purchase and install a 179.52 kilowatt (kW) solar photovoltaic system. Regenerative Ranch LLC is in El Prado, in Taos County, New Mexico. After the solar system is installed, the business will see $47,504 savings in their annual electric bill. It will generate 354,559 kilowatt hours (kWh) of electricity which is more than 100 percent of the electricity the business uses every year. The photovoltaic array will generate enough electricity to power 32 homes.

program: Rural Energy for America Program Renewable Energy Systems and Energy Efficiency Improvement Loans and Grants
funding_code: REAP IRA RES GRANT UNRESTRICTED (FY 22/23)
naics_industry_sector: Arts, Entertainment, and Recreation (71)
project_announced_description: This Rural Development investment will be used to purchase and install a 65.12 kilowatt (kW) solar photovoltaic system. Larry Bell Sculptures is in Taos, New Mexico and is best known for the glass boxes and large-scaled illusionistic sculptures. After the solar system is installed, the business will see $5,004 savings in their annual electric bill. It will generate 109,229 kilowatt hours (kWh) of electricity which is more than 152 percent of the electricity the business uses every year. The photovoltaic array will generate enough electricity to power 10 homes.

funding_code: COMMUNITY FACILITY (DIRECT AND GUARANTEED LOANS)
naics_industry_sector: Health Care and Social Assistance (62)
project_announced_description: This Rural Development investment will be used to construct and furnish a workforce development training facility at the Rocky Mountain Youth Corp (RMYC) located in Taos, New Mexico. The new facility will replace the current leased facility and provide an all-inclusive location for this entity since they own the land. This land has been used as RMYC ropes course and outdoor training center for 20 years. The new constructed facility interior spaces include four offices, a conference room, a training room, spaces for training and program operations, a kitchenette, storage space and a garage. The facility will include a classroom for RMYCs Training Department to offer workforce training and certifications to Corps members. The RMYC was founded in 1995 in response to an overwhelming need for positive solutions to the critical issues facing the Taos community youth and young adults. Through their program, RMYC fosters personal growth and leadership development, job skills, healthy decision making and community involvement among young people. The workforce training facility project will increase capacity for providing workforce development training to youth ages 14 - 25 who have limited access to the workforce and employment opportunities in the Taos area.

funding_code: (GRANT ONLY) PRE-DEVELOPMENT GRANTS - WASTE ONLY
naics_industry_sector: Utilities (22)
project_announced_description: This Rural Development investment will be used to help in the planning and development of phases to improve the wastewater treatment plant for the village of Questa. Located in the mountains of north central New Mexico Questa is 156 miles from Albuquerque, New Mexico. The current wastewater system operates with a clarifier pond, and it serves 1735 customers.The funding being provided by USDA Rural Development will be used to develop a preliminary engineering report to evaluate the current system and develop an environmental report. The report is needed to identify any inconsistencies and determine how to improve the wastewater system, and to determine if additional customers can be added to the system. Its hoped this initial investment for the village of Questa will assist in attaining its community improvement plans goals.

funding_code: FY22 CONGRESSIONALLY DIRECTED SPENDING
naics_industry_sector: Public Administration (92)
project_announced_description: This Rural Development investment will be used to build a fire station for the city of Moriarty, New Mexico. The proposed fire house will be between 13,000 and 15,000 square feet, which will be large enough to accommodate staff and equipment plus visitor parking. The structure will address safety deficiencies by providing larger living and work in addition to necessary storage. The design will improve the size and space for equipment and make the interior more functional. This project will also provide adequate space for both male and female personnel. The addition of the new fire station will provide better fire protection to the residents living in Moriarty.

funding_code: (COMB LOAN & GRANT) WATER ONLY
naics_industry_sector: Utilities (22)
project_announced_description: This Rural Development investment will be used to drill and install a new 600-foot deep, 12-inch diameter water well on a 1.5 acre fenced property owned by the city of Belen. The new water source is needed as an auxiliary and emergency backup supply of water to the citys Water Well #8. This well will also be connected to the newly completed Arsenic Treatment Facility filtration system which was funded by USDA Rural Development in 2019 and 2021. By connecting to the filtration system, the new well will also provide safe drinking water to the 7,400 residents living in the city of Belen.

funding_code: GUARANTEED B&I 3% FEE LOAN
naics_industry_sector: Manufacturing (31-33)
project_announced_description: This Rural Development investment will be used to provide long-term financing for the purchase of property to build and equip a manufacturing facility to supply pepper mash to various food manufacturers, restaurants, and retail stores. The borrower, Louisiana Pepper Exchange, LLC (LPE) is a North American pepper mash and puree supplier that currently sells product from its Louisiana facility. Pepper Mash is the primary ingredient in hot sauce but is also used to make other food such as condiments, cheese, bakery, and protein products. The new production facility will be located on a 10-acre greenfield site in the Ironhorse Industrial Park, in Santa Teresa, New Mexico. This site is in an ideal location because it will import the pepper mash from suppliers in Costa Rica, Colombia, Peru, and Mexico. Also, the location will allow LPE to better serve its customers in the Southwestern part of the United States through existing distribution contracts with various food distributors, restaurants, and retailers. The new site will increase manufacturing capacity and better supply the growing demand for their product. The project will create 15 jobs with an average annual wage of $25 per hour.

program: Rural Energy for America Program Renewable Energy Systems and Energy Efficiency Improvement Loans and Grants
funding_code: REAP IRA EEI GRANT $20K AND LESS (FY 23)
naics_industry_sector: Agriculture, Forestry, Fishing and Hunting (11)
project_announced_description: This Rural Development investment is being used to assist Del Valle Pecans LLC to upgrade the loft exhaust fan and fluorescent lighting to LED lamps, replacing outdated chest freezers (x4) with new Energy Star rated models, and adding insulation to the packaging/storage warehouse. Del Valle Pecans LLC is a pecan farm located in Mesilla Park, New Mexico. After the energy efficiency improvements are installed, the business will see $643 savings in their annual electric bill. It will save 4,612 kilowatt-hours (kWh) of electricity which is more than 71 percent of the electricity the business uses every year.

program: Rural Energy for America Program Renewable Energy Systems and Energy Efficiency Improvement Loans and Grants
funding_code: REAP-MANDATORY RENEW ENERGY SYST GRANTS
naics_industry_sector: Utilities (22)
project_announced_description: This Rural Development investment is being used to assist Dona Ana Biofuel and Nutrient Recovery Facility (DABNRF) purchase and install a state-of-the-art waste to energy project anaerobic digestion system including tanks. Located outside of Mesquite, in southern New Mexico, this facility will take cow manure from 20,000 cows located on four dairy farms within a six-mile radius of the project site and convert the raw material into natural gas and solid fertilizer. This gas will be injected into the Kinder Morgan pipeline approximately 3.2 miles to the southwest of the DABNRF via a pipeline interconnection. The digestate liquids will be sent to an evaporation pond. Digestate solids will be windrowed and turned for four to six weeks and then sold in bulk. All four farms, Mountain View, Bright Star, Del Oro and Sunset Dairy, are owned by the DeRuyter family.

funding_code: GUARANTEED B&I 3% FEE LOAN
naics_industry_sector: Accommodation and Food Services (72)
project_announced_description: This Rural Development investment will be used to renovate an existing Hampton Inn & Suites Hotel in Farmington, New Mexico. The hotel is a four-story building that has 73 rooms, including an indoor swimming pool, fitness room, business center, market pantry, and a guest laundry area. The borrower Elite Way Hospitality LLC. is a New Mexico limited liability company established on December 17, 2020, to develop, own, operate and provide quality hospitality services to the area year-round. Upon completion of the renovation, the hotel will have modernized amenities and will be able to provide continued quality service to the city of Farmington and surrounding areas. The hotel is expected to see expanded business because San Juan County is an economic hub that attracts commuters from surrounding counties. The market benefits from a variety of tourist and leisure attractions in the area, including the Four Corners Monument, Mesa Verde National Park, Chaco Canyon, and the annual Connie Mack World Series held every August. San Juan County continues to experience population and household growth as the city of Farmington continues to expand. The expanding population and labor force will create continued demand for providing community access for locals and tourists to affordable hospitality.
